pageProps.contentHtml:
entire functions, Jensen's formula

Let f ⁣:C→C\func{f}{\C}{\C}f:C→C be entire non-constant, and let us set

T(r)=12π∫02πlog⁡+∣f(reiφ)∣ dφ.T\p{r} = \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log_+\abs{f\p{re^{i\phi}}} \,\diff\phi.T(r)=2π1​∫02π​log+​∣∣​f(reiφ)∣∣​dφ.

Here log⁡+(s)=max⁡ {log⁡s,0}\log_+\p{s} = \max\,\set{\log{s}, 0}log+​(s)=max{logs,0}. Show that T(r)→∞T\p{r} \to \inftyT(r)→∞ as r→∞r \to \inftyr→∞.
Solution.

Since fff is non-constant, there exists n≥0n \geq 0n≥0 such that g(z)=f(z)zng\p{z} = \frac{f\p{z}}{z^n}g(z)=znf(z)​ is entire and g(0)≠0g\p{0} \neq 0g(0)=0. Then by subharmonicity,

log⁡ ∣g(0)∣≤12π∫02πlog⁡ ∣g(reiθ)∣ dθ≤12π∫02πlog⁡ ∣f(reiθ)∣ dθ−nlog⁡r≤T(r)−nlog⁡r.\begin{aligned} \log\,\abs{g\p{0}} &\leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\,\abs{g\p{re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta \\ &\leq \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\,\abs{f\p{re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta - n\log{r} \\ &\leq T\p{r} - n\log{r}. \end{aligned}log∣g(0)∣​≤2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​g(reiθ)∣∣​dθ≤2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​f(reiθ)∣∣​dθ−nlogr≤T(r)−nlogr.​

Suppose T(r)T\p{r}T(r) is bounded. Then if n≠0n \neq 0n=0, we may send r→∞r \to \inftyr→∞ to get log⁡ ∣g(0)∣=−∞\log\,\abs{g\p{0}} = -\inftylog∣g(0)∣=−∞, which would imply that g(0)=0g\p{0} = 0g(0)=0, which is impossible. Thus, f(0)≠0f\p{0} \neq 0f(0)=0 to begin with. In this case, we may apply Jensen's formula to get

log⁡ ∣f(0)∣+∑r<∣an∣<3rlog⁡3≤log⁡ ∣f(0)∣+∑∣an∣<3rlog⁡ 3r∣an∣=12π∫02πlog⁡ ∣f(3reiθ)∣ dθ≤T(3r),\begin{aligned} \log\,\abs{f\p{0}} + \sum_{r < \abs{a_n} < 3r} \log{3} &\leq \log\,\abs{f\p{0}} + \sum_{\abs{a_n} < 3r} \log\,\frac{3r}{\abs{a_n}} \\ &= \frac{1}{2\pi} \int_0^{2\pi} \log\,\abs{f\p{3re^{i\theta}}} \,\diff\theta \\ &\leq T\p{3r}, \end{aligned}log∣f(0)∣+r<∣an​∣<3r∑​log3​≤log∣f(0)∣+∣an​∣<3r∑​log∣an​∣3r​=2π1​∫02π​log∣∣​f(3reiθ)∣∣​dθ≤T(3r),​

where {an}n\set{a_n}_n{an​}n​ are the zeroes of fff. If fff only has finitely roots, then fff is a polynomial, so the sum has finitely many terms which grow like log⁡r\log{r}logr, which is impossible since T(r)T\p{r}T(r) is bounded. Finally, if fff has infinitely many zeroes, than the sum will diverge, since each term in the sum is strictly larger than 111. Hence, in all cases, we get a contradiction, so T(r)T\p{r}T(r) must be unbounded.
